newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Henderson cash call seen boosting growth.
newsitem.headline: Henderson cash call seen boosting growth.

text.p: Henderson Land Development Ltd has capitalised on its record high share price to raise fresh funds and Monday's HK$3.5 billion share placement should boost earnings growth at the company, analysts said on Tuesday.
The 55 million share placement at HK$64.00 per share was generally seen as an "opportunistic" placement after Henderson Land shares hit an all-time high of HK$66.50 on Monday.
"I think basically Henderson Land is taking advantage of the bullish outlook for its fundamentals in coming years," said Edward Chan, research director at NAVA SC Securities.
He raised his fiscal 1997 net profit forecast for the company by 1.4 percent to HK$11.05 billion and his fiscal 1998 forecast by 1.7 percent to HK$12.37 billion.
"Henderson Land's return on capital is about 25 percent, and if they have more new capital, I assume they would have better income," he said.

Desmond Cheung, analyst at Vickers Ballas, agreed. "The cost of capital for this HK$3.5 billion will be around six percent. The return on its investment is generally over 20 percent, therefore this should be beneficial to its earnings," he said.
Henderson Land shares had gained 8.6 percent as of Monday's close since the company reported fiscal 1996 earnings on September 11 of HK$8.36 billion compared to HK$7.03 billion.
"There is a need for more capital to maintain that growth in earnings," said Martin Tacon, analyst at HSBC James Capel.

"I think the desire and need to raise cash for long-term growth is always there and the timing depends on the market. I tend to say Henderson makes very good decisions in raising finance. I think their timing is good this time," he said.
Analysts said Henderson had taken advantage of an appetite for its shares in the market to raise fresh funds and the dilution impact of the placement would be minimal.

"It is very much oportunistic. They did not really need the money," said Andrew Taylor, analyst at Asia Equity, adding that Henderson Land shares were trading around net asset value of between HK$64 and HK$66.
However, analysts said other developers wanting to take advantage of market buoyancy to raise cash may not find it as easy as Henderson Land.
"To raise cash in this kind of interest rate environment needs orchestration," said Franklin Lam, director of research at HG Asia.
"I think investors will look for some guarantee that the aftermarket will be good," he said.
Chan said property sales and profit growth at other developers may not be as good as Henderson Land's. "I think the response may not be so overwhelming," he said.
Analysts said Henderson Land shares were likely to come under short-term pressure following the placement.
On Tuesday, they ended HK$2.25 lower at HK$64.00.

"Whenever there is a placement, one always feels that the company is making a statement in terms of the valuation of the stock. Henderson has had a good run and it is an indication that the company feels that at these levels the stock could be fairly valued," said Tacon.
However, analysts saw more upside later for the shares.
"I think the current price level is quite demanding but with the return from property sales, the stock should reach over HK$70 in the next 12 months," said Cheung.

Lam said the market's appetite for property stocks was strong despite an expected rise in interest rates in the United States. "That bodes well for developer stocks going into the next quarter or so and I do expect more upside for developers stocks between now and the end of the year," he said.
-- Hong Kong Newsroom (852) 2843 6345
